author: PEDRO MOURA
title: Moura: Gotham loves its new villian in Chase Utley
text:
By PEDRO MOURA / STAFF WRITER
 Updated: 10:49 p.m. NEW YORK – For 12 seconds Monday night, the citizens of New York booed Chase Utley with all their might, and Utley stared back at them with all of his.
Sometime in between the slide heard ’round the world Saturday night in Los Angeles and Monday night’s resumption of the Dodgers-Mets set, it became apparent that this city’s upgraded hate for Utley could transcend the third game of this National League Division Series.
Apparent enough that Dodgers manager Don Mattingly declined to use Utley at all in the game, even in situations he normally would.
Apparent enough that Mattingly spent part of his pregame news conference talking about safety in today’s society, and the need to ensure Utley and his family would not feel in danger at Citi Field on Monday night.
Apparent enough that commissioner Rob Manfred held an emergency meeting before the game between Mattingly, Mets manager Terry Collins, and the team’s decision makers, Andrew Friedman and Sandy Alderson, to make clear his expectations: They must not embarrass baseball on a national stage.
“l’m really confident that the game will overtake this story,” Manfred said.
It did not seem to. It may soon, but, only in the event that the Dodgers’ season ends and the Mets’ campaign continues.
The largest crowd in Citi Field history booed Utley with fervor during the on-field introductions. The cameraman and scoreboard operator kept his face on the massive screen twice as long as his teammates, and the anti-Utley chants never stopped for long in the Dodgers’ four-hour, 13-7 loss to the Mets.
“I think the boos at the introductions were kind of a big statement leading into the game,” Mets starter Matt Harvey said. “We knew the biggest thing going in was coming on top and scoring as many runs as we did, and, you know, that kind of did all the talking. So, for us, it was to stay focused, go out and let our play do all the talking.”
Somehow, September’s Harvey storyline seems too far away. It was once unclear whether he’d even be available in the postseason. He and his agent talked about innings limits and concerns about the long-term safety of his arm. It dominated this city’s media landscape for the better part of a week. Monday night, the Mets ace did not pitch particularly well in his playoff debut, and it was a non-story.
A story once again is the Dodgers’ impending doom, and how their situation is remarkably similar to what it was a year ago at this time. To survive, they need Clayton Kershaw to pitch well and for a long time, and then they need Zack Greinke to do the same.
Should they somehow win these next two games against the Mets and advance, similar fortunes seem to wait. The problems that plagued them in the past still do. All Mattingly could say after Monday night’s game was that Brett Anderson and Alex Wood have been “OK”. They are his options to start game beyond Kershaw and Greinke
“You know, yeah, they’ve been fine,” Mattingly said.
Even Tuesday, should Kershaw tire early on short rest, who will pitch the seventh inning? Pedro Baez, the man who did Friday night and gave up the winning hit, and then struggled again Monday?
There are problems without solutions, and solutions do not often appear in the middle of October.
